Award.AwardTitle: A New Approach to the Measurement of Economic Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs want to develop a new method to collect economic data on the behavior of households and individuals. They wish to gather data from people who have already agreed to participate in a new survey, the Understanding America Study (UAS). The UAS gathers data on a representative sample of US residents using internet-based methods, including measures of financial literacy, numeracy, personality time use, health, and demographics. The award funds a pilot study to expand the UAS to include data on financial transactions, balances and expenditures. The data would be gathered with the participants' consent directly from the electronic records of a financial information aggregation firm. The project will give us new information about the possible feasibility of one alternative to the survey methods that are now used to gather data about consumer expenditures. The results could lead to better data for public policy and for the business community, since the project could increase the speed, breadth, and reliability of economic data.

The UAS panel is a population-representative household panel currently implemented by the University of Southern California. The project will evaluate the feasibility of collecting financial administrative data from households. Current data are generally collected via surveys, and this means that there are specific sources of measurement error that may not apply to administrative records. Electronic administrative records may allow for a reduction in respondent burden while allowing for real-time data collection. The study will allow the PIs to determine whether the administrative data are more reliable and more extensive than the existing survey measures in practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A New Approach to the Measurement of Economic Behavior

Project Outcomes Statement

 

This study has explored the feasibility of a new approach to the way economic data are collected and made available for research. In the project we have collected data on household financial transactions, balances, and expenditures from electronic records of respondents in the Understanding America Study (UAS), a population-representative household Internet panel. The UAS panel members participating in the project have agreed to sharing passwords with a financial aggregation firm, so that the company can aggregate information across the various accounts a panel member may have. The data can be combined with survey information from the panel and made available to the research community with minimal delay.

 

Earlier work has used electronic transaction data provided by financial aggregation firms, generating large samples of accurate financial transactions. One of the challenges with such data is selectivity. Individuals who voluntarily sign up to use services of financial aggregator firms are more likely to be male, to be 25-44 years of age, and are less likely to have a graduate degree than the average person living in the U.S. Another issue is that such data provide a partial picture of the financial transactions and balances of a couple or household. The individual signs up accounts that s/he has with different financial institutions, including joint accounts s/he may share with a partner. However, the data do not include the individual accounts of one’s partner. Moreover, the amount of demographic information available tends to be limited.

 

The approach we have followed in the UAS addresses a number of these issues, as we can supplement electronic data with survey data, while rich background data are available to address selectivity and other sampling issues.  On the other hand, at this point samples tend to be small, at least partly due to the cost of providing incentives to panel members to participate in projects like these.

 

After an initial pilot of 100 UAS respondents we invited an additional 1,010 panel members to participate. Out of the 1,107 who answered the consent form, 508 stated they would be willing to participate in the study, for a 46% realized consent rate. After agreeing to participate in the study, respondents had to take several steps to be able to actually participate. They have to sign up at the web-site (https://uasfin.usc.edu) we have developed specifically for the project. 350 panel members signed up for an account on https://uasfin.usc.edu; next they had to link accounts and finally they had to keep the accounts up-to-date – 135 panel members linked their financial institution and kept them active. We have undertaken several activities to reduce attrition at each of these steps, including follow up phone calls and sending additional educational materials.

 

We have used the preliminary data to replicate results by Gelman et al., (2014). We show that the total number of accounts per respondent is similar in the two studies. On the other hand, our respondents exhibit a significantly smaller number of daily transactions, as well as lower credit card balances and credit limits than those in the Gelman et al, (2014) study. We attribute these observed differences to selectivity issues mentioned above. We also study the issue of consumption smoothing over pay cycles. In line with the literature, we find evidence of consumers’ inability to smooth consumption between paydays. Unlike previous studies relying on electronic transaction information from financial aggregators, our data allow us to explore heterogeneity in consumer behavior as driven by demographics, health, cognitive ability and financial literacy, among others. Our results indicate that consumers with lower cognitive capabilities and lower education are less able to smooth their consumption.

 

We have compared self-reported expenditure measures to actual measures obtained from transactional data for a variety of spending categories with the goal of evaluating the reliability of self-reported expenditures elicited via survey questions. Overall, we observe less variation and less skewness in self-reported monthly expenditures than in measured expenditures. A plausible explanation of this pattern is that self-reports over longer periods, like a month, partly reflect “normal” or “typical” expenditures, rather than precise fluctuations from month to month. We also find that for larger expenditures, like spending on restaurants, self-reports and measured expenditures provide similar outcomes, while for smaller expenditures such as utilities, the distribution of self-reports and transactional measures can be quite different.

Our work has attracted the interest of a non-academic partner. This partner will be funding expansion of the data collection, building on the experience gained in the current project. The ambition is to collect data among a much larger sample than has proved to be feasible until now (on the order of 1000 participants), while the time horizon is indefinite.
